title: 111_s2951
content: The "Blue Ridge Parkway Protection Act" defines key terms such as Director, Parkway, Plan, Secretary, and Superintendent. The Act also includes findings related to the Blue Ridge Parkway. The Blue Ridge Parkway, the most visited unit of the National Park System, is vital to the economic well-being of communities along its 469-mile stretch in North Carolina and Virginia. The Parkway's scenic vistas are threatened by development, and conservation efforts help preserve farmland, forests, and wildlife. Parkway conservation efforts are crucial to preserving farmland, intact forests, wildlife habitat, and drinking water supplies downstream. It is essential to conserve lands contiguous to the Parkway to maintain its natural beauty, ecological integrity, and cultural heritage for future generations. Land acquisition is essential for preserving the natural beauty, ecological integrity, and cultural heritage of the Parkway. The Secretary is authorized to acquire up to 50,000 acres of land for the Parkway from willing sellers through donation, purchase, or exchange. The acquired lands must be contiguous with the Parkway and identified as a priority for acquisition. The Plan for land acquisition is available for public inspection, and the Parkway boundary will be adjusted accordingly after acquisition. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land for the Parkway from willing sellers through donation, purchase, or exchange. The acquired lands will be administered by the Secretary through the National Park Service in accordance with all applicable laws and regulations. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorized funding of $15,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2011 through 2015 to acquire land and provide technical assistance for land acquisition through grants to non-profit conservation organizations. Unobligated funds are available until expended. The Superintendent has identified specific priorities for funding. The Secretary can allocate up to 10% of funds for site restoration and resource surveys. Additionally, up to $250,000 annually from 2011 to 2015 can be used to reimburse administrative expenses for non-profit conservation organizations involved in land acquisition projects for the Parkway. Funds are available for land acquisition to protect the Parkway and will not expire. SEC. 6. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the condition of the Parkway, completed or ongoing land acquisitions, and priority land acquisitions needed to fulfill the Act's purpose.
